title: 110_s31
content: The Act titled "H-1B Visa Fraud Prevention Act of 2007" requires H-1B employers to meet certain requirements. The H-1B Visa Fraud Prevention Act of 2007 prohibits outplacement of H-1B nonimmigrants to different state worksites by employers. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act and effective date are specified. The H-1B Visa Fraud Prevention Act of 2007 prohibits outplacement of H-1B nonimmigrants to different state worksites by employers. An amendment is added requiring employers to share all immigration paperwork with employees or beneficiaries upon request. The H-1B Visa Fraud Prevention Act of 2007 prohibits outplacement of H-1B nonimmigrants to different state worksites by employers. An amendment requires employers to share all immigration paperwork with employees or beneficiaries upon request. SEC. 3. H-1B GOVERNMENT AUTHORITY AND REQUIREMENTS. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act enhances safeguards against fraud and misrepresentation in the application review process for employers hiring H-1B nonimmigrants. It includes requirements for clear indicators of fraud, misrepresentation of material fact, and accuracy in the application submission process. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act strengthens measures to prevent fraud and misrepresentation in H-1B nonimmigrant application reviews by allowing investigations for clear indicators of fraud or misrepresentation. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act enhances measures to detect fraud and misrepresentation in H-1B nonimmigrant applications by allowing investigations based on indicators of fraud or misrepresentation. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows investigations into employer compliance with requirements, including providing notice before conducting an investigation. The amendment to the Immigration and Nationality Act allows the Secretary of Labor to investigate employer compliance with requirements and provide notice of any determination, with an opportunity for a hearing within 120 days. The Secretary of Labor may impose a penalty if there is a violation of requirements under the subsection, not made in good faith. Information sharing between the Department of Labor and Department of Homeland Security is required. The Secretary may investigate noncompliance with H-1B visa program requirements and conduct audits to ensure employer compliance. Penalties for violations have been increased to $2,000. In amendments to the H-1B visa program, penalties for violations have been increased to $2,000. Additionally, upon issuing an H-1B visa, the applicant will receive a brochure outlining employer obligations and employee rights under Federal law, along with contact information for Federal agencies for further assistance. Upon issuance of an H-1B visa, the applicant will receive a brochure outlining employer obligations and employee rights under Federal law, along with contact information for Federal agencies for further assistance. SEC. 4. H-1B whistleblower protections amended to include actions by employers and liability for violations. SEC. 5. Director of USCIS to submit fraud risk assessment of H-1B visa program to Congress within 30 days of enactment.
